data.title: Fix crash when unsharing a range that is not shared
data.body:
Added a guard to Range::_unref_shared to prevent it from doing anything
in the event that shared is null.

Fixes Issue: #11521

data.title: Can't open editor or exported game in linux environment without WM and DM
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Debian Buster in a VM running on VirtualBox
No WM or DM installed, just X (`xserver-xorg`, `xinit`)
Godot 2.1.4

**Issue description:**
Trying to create a gaming system with a godot application as graphical menu.
When system boots, X is started and calls godot application
The following error is displayed:

    X Error of failed request: BadAtom (invalid Atom parameter)
      Major opcode of failed request: 18 (X_ChangeProperty)
      Atom id in failed request: 0x0
      Serial number of failed request: 36
      Current serial number in output stream: 40

output of `strace -e open,stat godot`: https://pastebin.com/STdZnMvD
long output of complete strace: https://paste.debian.net/988107/

**Steps to reproduce:**
Try start X with godot directly

data.title: Strange scrolling behaviour when using the function shortcut list in script editor
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Win10, current build.

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
When using the functions shortcut list in the script editor, the editor is not scrolling to the correct location much of the time. It seems that as you go down the function list, the highlighted portion scrolls to the bottom of the editor. As you go up the function list the editor is scrolled correctly with the highlighted function being at the top of the script editor.

The following gif illustrates this behaviour:
![cam1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7741669/30949593-b0691980-a45a-11e7-85ea-b7122ab5c024.gif)



**Steps to reproduce:**
- successively go down the functions shortcut list, and then go back up the list and note the scrolling function 


**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Sheen
Several visual improvements.
data.body:
Added proper label sizing
Improved text editor status bar
now it the margins are correct, and also it uses code font (which is better to read errors)
![screenshot from 2017-09-27 15-38-55](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1103897/30944428-4c72892c-a3bd-11e7-9ee8-23539da562ae.png)

Fixed some issues with ItemList and also some style fixes

improved editor file dialog, now it matches the back and forward icons, plus the side panel is resizable.
![screenshot from 2017-09-27 19-47-37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1103897/30944457-84033080-a3bd-11e7-8a54-2f55aad6eaf5.png)

now also includes the @mrcdk fixes for color picker.

data.title: Same shader applied on lines and plane outputs different color
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master
Windows 10 64 bits
nVidia 940M

I noticed that if I output pure white as ALBEDO in a shader, it shows white on a plane, but dark blue on lines in a test project with default environment and a directional light, as if it was constantly in shadow. Same with an empty environment: quad is white, lines are black.
It's fairly minor though, because using `shader_mode unshaded;` let you output the color directly, bypassing shadows.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/30943849-1bb397ea-a3f4-11e7-86c0-0ead28db2877.png)

Shader:
```
shader_type spatial;

void fragment() {
	ALBEDO = vec3(1,1,1);
}
```

Project:
[LineColorShader.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/1339070/LineColorShader.zip)

data.title: There is no "parent folder" button in project manager browser
data.body:
Godot 3.0 master

There is no way to go to the parent folder when browsing for a folder to create a project. The only way I found is to edit the path. There should be a button like any other filesystem dialog. (the circle arrow button doesn't do this)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1311555/30943472-775fa50a-a3f1-11e7-983f-c07c8ec4307e.png)

data.title: using "is" with gdscript class on both sides fail
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Ubuntu 17.04, godot master da144fed4c49133a93b3b83cfc665352c0af351a

**Issue description:**
Checking if an instance that inherits a gdscript class is an instance of a gdscript class fails with ```Internal Script Error - opcode #31 (report please)```

Pretty sure this was introduced in https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/11518 just like https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/11595

**Steps to reproduce:**
```
class ClassA:
	var x
	
func _ready():
	ClassA.new() is Node # works
	Node.new() is ClassA # works
	ClassA.new() is ClassA # Internal Script Error - opcode #31
```

data.title: Opening a Visualscript file opens 2 files in the editor
data.body:
**Operating system or device, Godot version, GPU Model and driver (if graphics related):**
Godot 3.0 master https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/da144fed4c49133a93b3b83cfc665352c0af351a

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
I don't know what happened but after opening and closing the file a couple times when I opened it two files were open the script itself and the same one but with no name:
![https://i.imgur.com/84bKdCN.gifv](https://i.imgur.com/84bKdCN.gif)

(the broken editor problem is here https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/11636)

**Steps to reproduce:**
I'm not really sure. I noticed that the opened script was marked with a `(*)` when opening it and when closing the editor it doesn't complain that it's not saved. There were no new modifications in that script so it shouldn't show the `(*)`.

data.title: Fix remove icon in autoload panel
Using a setget set function on multiple values - without value = newvalue inside the function
data.body:
Basically I am trying to implement an undo system in my application. At first I thought that using setget on all values that I want to revert upon undo would be ideal, but I quickly found out that there is a flaw in this logic- I cant use a single function to do it.

I want to do something like this:
```
var layerVisible = true setget storeUndoStep
var layerPosition = Vector2(0,0) setget storeUndoStep

```
Using setget to call a function that stores the old value to an array, every time a value is changed.
The problem is:

Setget's function needs to assign the new value, you cant just grab the old value before it's changed. You have to also assign it in the function - this makes it impossible to reuse the same function on multiple variables. You have to create a separate storeUndo function for every single variable that changes. Is it possible to use setget only to trigger a function, but let godot write the new value without doing
`value = newvalue `
inside the setget function?

my plan for the undo system is:
undosteps = [[all values undo step 1],[all values undo step 2],[all values undo step 3]...]

So on each undoable value change, use set get to append all current values array to the undosteps array

Perhaps I should use the get function?

data.title: Fixed error when extending another class in GDscript
data.body:
commit 520d84e042bcc5d211950022abb40ff7cc90b15b introduced a bug where `extend`ing from another class/script failed with `Internal Script Error - opcode #18.`

this removes the mistakenly placed `OPCODE_BREAK` and fixes #11595

data.title: Depth test mode support added to materials.
data.body:
This adds the ability to override depth function operand on materials. The default depth function is lesser or equal, but by overriding this, you can create some potentially interesting special effects. For example, you could have a two pass material with the second pass being a flat shaded colour using the greater-than depth function so that it can appear as a silhouette when obscured by geometry.

![depth](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12756047/30890630-ed10ee7a-a325-11e7-993f-d88a8a97a2d3.png)

There is already a flag in materials to outright disable depth testing, and this PR might make that redundant, but I've decided to leave it for now.

There's  also an important limitation of this PR which I feel needs to be addressed in a separate issue. Right now, the renderer only batches two render lists, one for opaque and one for translucent objects, with the translucent list being rendered last. Since materials using the greater-than operand needs to always be rendered AFTER what it is being rendered behind, the only current way to handle this is make sure that the material using the greater-than operand is marked as translucent, so that it will render after all the opaque objects have already been rendered. This is not ideal since you don't have much fine-grained control, and translucent objects obviously are marked to not further contribute to the depth buffer. A way to solve this issue would be to provide more fine-grained access to the order in which objects are rendered, maybe some kind of ID to ensure a particular group of materials are always rendered after another group. This actually should be very easy to implement, but does probably require some discussion on the best way to go about it.
